Posts.Content: Feb 8, 2009 08:26PM Jamie6 wrote: Kathy - good luck w/your surgery, too!  I hope we both come back to post our experiences shortly after returning home from the hospital.  Those that have posted ahead of us have done tremendous service, and I'd love to join them in adding and contributing to this forum.   Catch you back in here real soon ~! Jamie
Posts.Title: February Surgery jillisucat 2new1s

Posts.Content: Feb 14, 2009 08:25PM Jamie6 wrote: Hi Jillisucat, Sorry to hear that your experience at the hospital was so unimaginable!  I'm glad you had good team of medical professionals around you where you were, and that you are now recovering. Your story reminds me of why I get a little worried about hospitals sending us home so quickly after procedures such as ours.  I had my bilat-mx with TE on Monday, Feb 9, and post surgery I was running a fever of 100.7 as well as being very anemic (rbc count down to 6 where norm is around 12).  They still told me,  "It's up to you if you want to stay another night".  Not that I minded going home after one night, as I may have rested better at home, but there was no way I could monitor my anemia which seemed to be alarming the nurses, and I figured I'd be better off left at the hospital for observation and monitoring I could not do from home for myself.  Nothing at all like what you experrienced during your hospital stay, so I can't complain.  However, in my case, I have to say that the rating on the staff at my hospital was 50-50.  Some were great, and some were obviously just putting in their hours and didn't really want to be bothered - LOL. Doctors and nurses always seemed to have difference in opinions, and I was starting to get very confused listening to them separately.  I'm glad I'm home now, but I'm left with a lot of pills to keep track of on my own.  Large doses of iron pills (makes me constipated!), antibiotics, pain pills, and anti-nausea pills.  I must confess, the nausea wins out of all of them.  I can pretty much deal with the other discomforts, but with this constant nausea, it's been quite a miserrable week so far for me. I wish you all a very quick recovery  - one day at a time, as I am told :-).  Hang in there, and know that my prayers are with you all. xoxoxo Jamie6
Posts.Title: February Surgery jillisucat 2new1s

Posts.Content: Feb 26, 2009 01:24PM Jamie6 wrote: Bee, Remember that they need to fill you one size larger than the final implant size, so for example, if I fill until I look like a C cup, I will end up with a B cup finish.  Keep that in mind when you're gauging by eye-balling the size, which is what I'm probably going to do for myself.  This breast reconsttruction deal is the only thing that feels positive out of this whole breast cancer experience, so I'm going to try to have fun with it all the way through - LOL
Posts.Title: February Surgery jillisucat 2new1s

Posts.Content: Feb 7, 2009 06:34PM Jamie6 wrote: Hi people,  I'm scheduled for bilateral mastectomy with TE in two days (February 9, 2009).  If I can kick the fever I've been running for the last few days by 5am on surgery day, I should be able to get operated.  Having a cold just prior to surgery has been a bitch - as though I don't have enough on my mind - LOL. good luck to everyone - and keep on posting pre-and post-ops! Jamie
Posts.Title: February Surgery jillisucat 2new1s

Posts.Content: Feb 7, 2009 10:06PM Jamie6 wrote: 2new1's - thank you for your well wishes.   I expect to get my fever down just in time :) Bee54 - congrats on completing your surgery.  Glad to hear that it wasn't too bad for you.  It gives me hope that I can get as lucky as you did.  I don't know why, but I have to go get sentnel node dye injection tomorrow morning, one day before surgery.  Did you all have that done the day prior, or did you get it on the day of the surgery?  I don't know why they need to torture me on my last "free" day - LOL. okay, I will post more with the lastest.  Take care to you all :)
Posts.Title: February Surgery jillisucat 2new1s

Posts.Content: Mar 4, 2009 07:53PM Jamie6 wrote: Swimangel, I got my "vasular invasion negative" noted on my pathology report when I got my stereotactic biopsy prior to my surgery.  After my surgery, the same conclusion was noted on my final pathology report post surgery.  Of course, they did not know that I was lymph node negative until after the surgery was performed, but the status of vasular invasion (in my case negative) was noted prior to surgery, so for what's it's worth, I don't know if the determination was based on my biopsy and confirmed at surgery  or whatever???  /?To be more specifit, in my first pathology report, it said "negative for lympho vascular invasion".  All I know is that this was a good thing.  I don't think this determination came from my blood tests.  It was definitely from tissue samples in my case.
Posts.Title: Anyone declining further treatment after bilateral? karen_3 Jamie6

Posts.Content: Mar 5, 2009 12:45PM Jamie6 wrote: D-Anne, Welcome, and I too, am sorry you have to join us here.  However, there is no nicer place to be in terms of getting tremendous support and information.  It's God-sent that you get to hear so many personal accounts from various people in here, rather than reading texts and research reports written by medical professionals who have not had BC personally.  Information from all sources are important and helpful, but there is nothing like getting the actual in depth experience people in here are willing to share to ease your mind and help you through this difficult period. I'm fairly new, but believe you me... you will become so knowledgeable about BC in a super short amount of time once you get it yourself and start talking to many people.  Everyone is anxious to share info and extend loving supports. No question is dumb or insignificant, so ask away~! Hope you keep posting
Posts.Title: Anyone declining further treatment after bilateral? karen_3 Jamie6

Posts.Content: Feb 28, 2009 07:08PM Jamie6 wrote: LOL - I'll stay in one room instead of switching back and forth between here and the other one to read your responses.  I'm now clear as to 2-3 weeks of wait time (vs 7 weeks due to inadequate amount of sample submitted the first time... how annoying is that??? LOL). Thanks again for all the info, Rockwell~!
Posts.Title: Anyone declining further treatment after bilateral? karen_3 Jamie6

Posts.Content: Feb 28, 2009 06:33PM Jamie6 wrote: Rockwell - I'm presuming that my oncologist is the one that does my oncotype testing?  If so, then I meet with her for the fist time this coming Tuesday.  Does it take a long time to get the result back? I'm so happy for you that you got to skip chemo.  That must have been a relief.  As for Tamoxifen, I suppose it would be a good deal in exchange for chemo +/- radiation, but I'm upset about the high likelyhood of  getting pushed into early menopause by this drug.  My doc also told me about the increased risk of cervical cancer with Tamoxifen.  Of course, you have to weigh everything and take the lesser of 2 evils, but my goodness, I wish the decision making was easier than it's been so far.  For example, if my onco type score was 16-17 like you did, I would probably agree with Tamoxifen, but what if I were to score much lower?  Then what do I do?  I guess I'll come back and gather the opinions of my sisters in here once I'm at that bridge :-)
Posts.Title: Anyone declining further treatment after bilateral? karen_3 Jamie6

Posts.Content: Mar 2, 2009 12:55PM Jamie6 wrote: Karen - AMEN!  I hear you loud and clear   I'm thinking exactly the same - if it's a matter of going form 10% to 5%, I'm passing.  If double digits are involved, I will naturally consider taking the treatment. Before my surgery, my primary care physiain jumped to the conclusion and said to me, "mastectomy, preferably bilateral, followed by chemo and radiaion - you're talking being in treatment for at least 6-9 months".  My breast surgeon, prior to my surgery said, "Tamoxifen likely - but if lymph nodes involved, definitely chemo". Well, post surgery, my pathology report was much better than anyone expected.  Now my PCP has no more comments (which I suppose is normal, now that I'm under specialists), and my BS told me that she would not prescribe any treatments personally, but to go ahead and meet with the oncologist anyway.  I meet my onc tomorrow.  I bet you $100 she's going to say Tamoxifen - LOL.  I'll post tomorrow to let you know - LOL
Posts.Title: Anyone declining further treatment after bilateral? karen_3 Jamie6

Posts.Content: Mar 3, 2009 08:30AM Jamie6 wrote: Buy a Volvo, have a BC - lol that's a good one.   Although the current stat I now hear is 1 out of every 7 women getting BC (it used to be 1/10 several years ago, and it was 1/8 only few years ago), yesterday I heard 1 out of every 3.  Whaaaaat?  Perhaps this new stat means if you don't get BC, you will certainly know someone who has or had BC.  1 out of 3?  How could that be?  Is it the change in our life styles over the recent decades, or is it simply that more and more people are reporting their diagnosis  - or simply more and more people are going for check ups than before and therefore has gotten flagged?  Is something going on in the environment I'm not aware of?  I knew better than to touch tap water in Long Island (highest rate of breast cancer in the country), and I drank botttled water pretty much for my entire residency here.  That didn't help much, did it? LOL.  Whatever the case may be, it seems hell of a lot more common than I was once lead to believe.
Posts.Title: Anyone declining further treatment after bilateral? karen_3 Jamie6

Posts.Content: Mar 4, 2009 08:01PM Jamie6 wrote: oh goodness, I posted the above in response to Swimangel regarding vascular invasion because I could have sworn I saw her post a question about it just a while ago.  Now her question post has disappeared, and my reply post sounds ilke that of a babbling of a mad woman - LOL.  Sorry if I hallucinated and read an imaginary post.  I hope it's my computer playing tricks on me instead of my brain.  Karen - can't wait to see you post in here again after you recover enough from your surgery.  My constant prayers are with you~!
Posts.Title: Anyone declining further treatment after bilateral? karen_3 Jamie6

Posts.Content: Feb 28, 2009 05:44PM Jamie6 wrote: Karen, I'm meeting with my oncologist for the first time on Tuesday, and I'm hoping that I don't need any further treatment after my bilateral mastectomy 3 weeks ago.  However, I'm still menstruating so that may prompt my oncologist to recommend at least Tamoxifen, if nothing else.  My breast surgeon's opinion was that for the likes of me, the possible negative side effects from taking Tamoxifen outweighs the benefits, so she thinks I can pass on it.  It was nice to hear my BS say that~!  In the end, if my oncologist can convince me that I am at high risk of recurrence AND that there will be  significant reduction in possible recurrence if I take the treatment, I will probably take my onc's advice.     I've been amazed at how many decisions were left "up to me" by my various doctors upon being diagnosed till my breasts were removed 3 weeks later.  I fear that I'm going to hear the same thing again when I visit my oncologist.  At times, I wish I can be told more decisive recommendations from my doctors instead!  I get more education from this forum than I do from my medical appointments - LOL.
Posts.Title: Anyone declining further treatment after bilateral? karen_3 Jamie6

Posts.Content: Mar 3, 2009 07:36PM Jamie6 wrote: Well, I met with my oncologist for the first time today.  she's sending out for onco-type test for me, so I have to return in about 2 weeks to discuss the result.  The impression I got from this oncologist is that she is pro-chemo regardless of what my score turns out to be simply because she thinks anyone my age should do chemo either way (42)!  I know she's trying to cover all grounds for me and do everything to increase my odd of not having recurrence, but I was a little surprised that she had her mind made up on what she wanted to personally recommend prior to the test result.  Tamoxofin was a given, she said, and that will be prescribed to ANYONE she  meets with.  Okay, I can live with that one, but chemo too?  I  thought Tamoxifen was going to be enough for the likes of me, especially if my score came back low.  However, she did look at my pahtology report and was delightfully amused at how unagressive my type of cancer was despite my age.  I have a degree in biochemistry, so I kind of understand the pathology report  on cellular  level myselff, so I asked my oncologist if after reading all the good stuff on my path report and understanding my family history (I'm the first in my DYNASTY to have BC - lol - and genetic testing revealed negative for BRCA 1 & 2), would she still recommend chemo even if I score low on the onco-type test, and she actually looked confused because she did want to say "yes" but she realized I was such an oddity in terms of why I even got cancer, and how low grade and unaggressive my cancer had been despite my age she kept using as her reason for prescribing chemo.    It almost felt like I was talking to a programmed pro-chemo robot that got short curcuited when challenged with questions as to why she would push chemo on a woman with low score and low risk.  She kept changing the subject instead of answering that question I asked more than once.  She wrapped up the session with, "Why don't you go home and have a glass of wine to celebrate, since you're technically cancer free right.  Your surgeon got everything out, and as far as I'm concerned, you're got the 'all clear' for now".  How confusing is that, to be told just a second ago I should get chemo, and then be told that I'm cancer free so go have a toast.  I simply answered meekly, "I don't drink alcohol, but I will go and celebrate, thank you".   She then looked embarrassed at recommending alcohol to a non-drinker (clearely stated in the Q&A I had to furnish just prior to talking to her).  Out of nowhere, she then recommended I take up yoga or some exercise to help me feel  even better.  She ignored my resume that stated I'm a certified  ballroom dance instructor on the side, where I dance 5 hours every evening, 5 days a week (except during this surgury recovery time recently, of course).   I have nothing against this oncologist, but it may not hurt for me to get a second opinion in my case - LOL.  A friend I brought with me to listen to my oncologist commented, "she looks like she's barely out of college - in her mid 20's".  It was difficult to tell becasue she was an Oriental  lady and they do tend  to look much younger than their age - LOL.
Posts.Title: Anyone declining further treatment after bilateral? karen_3 Jamie6

Posts.Content: Mar 14, 2009 04:34PM Jamie6 wrote: I've never taken any types of birth control pills in my entire life.  I'm still here in this forum - LOL.  Karen,  I hope you're recovering nicely from your recent surgery.  It's easy to run yourself down with strings of sleepless nights doing research (done that myself - LOL), so just be careful and allow yourself to recover as much as you can right now.  Sleep depravation has done me more harm than anything else so far, and by the 3rd week, I was doing worse than my first week post surgery!  I finally took control of that issue, and am finally starting to feel better each day.  Just try to take it easy on yourself for the first few weeks, hon!
Posts.Title: Anyone declining further treatment after bilateral? karen_3 Jamie6

Posts.Content: Mar 3, 2009 08:26PM Jamie6 wrote: Thank you Swimangel & Rockwell - I appreciate the positive vibes you're sending my way. No, I did not even have vascular invasion - LOL  That's what I mean by me getting so lucky wit every bits of my path report.  Cells were well differentiated (best cagtegory out of 3 possible ones), no vascular invasion, no lymph involvements, blah blah blah - all good news relatively speaking.  Yes, I will wait until onco-type test result comes back before seeking second opinion, as I will need that report to take with me to my second doctor anyway :-).  Thank you , and I will keep you posted~!  (I'm glad to hear that you got second opinion too, even though your first one already delivered the good news of no chemo.  I would have been happy enough to stop there, but you' were smart for getting another opinion cuz you never know!).
Posts.Title: Anyone declining further treatment after bilateral? karen_3 Jamie6

Posts.Content: Mar 4, 2009 08:23PM Jamie6 wrote: Phew - that's good that you saw the post too.  Yeah, I'll leave my reply there too, since others might benefit.
Posts.Title: Anyone declining further treatment after bilateral? karen_3 Jamie6

Posts.Content: Feb 17, 2009 05:39PM Jamie6 wrote: I only had tumor on the right breast, but had SNB on both, and had bilateral mastectomy last week.  So far, neither of my arms have any problems at all.  BTW, my nodes came back cancer-free during their "quick test" so that was nice.  I'll have the final pahtology report in a day or two to confirm this good news or ruin my day if the report comes back with microscopic findings that the "quick test" didn't detect.  Either way, I don't regret getting SNB on both sides since I got lucky from not having any negative effects so far. Good luck :-)
Posts.Title: SNB with Bi-lateral Mastectomy? BonnieKJG BonnieKJG

Posts.Content: Apr 7, 2009 10:41PM Jamie6 wrote: You sound like you're doing all the right things already . I would not underestimate stress though... I think prolonged period of stress is culpable to many health problems, and could even contribute to cancer, since it will lower your immune system.  Also, sleep deprivation.... ahhhh... I bet my insomnia-like condition I've had for over a decade may have done additional damage to my immune system.  After my BC diagnosis, it only got worse.  I think there was an article about a link between BC and lack of sleep.  I didn't book mark the article, but you can Google it you're interested in the study. Again, I think you're doing pretty good on your own to reduce risk all you possible can! Good luck :-)
Posts.Title: Are you doing anything to reduce your breast cancer risk? kibbles lexislove

Posts.Content: Mar 23, 2009 11:58AM Jamie6 wrote: I know it's by individual cases how quickly you recover, but in my case, if I had not had my immediate breast reconstruction with tissue expanders in place, I probably would have been doing fine after 4 weeks.  My drains took 10-15 days to come out because of my tissue expanders, but to be honest, I was feeling great after just 1 week (despite the drain tubes). The day I got my drain tubes out completely after 2 weeks, I immediately hit the gym to resume my normal physical activities and exercises.  I did take it easy when it came to lifting or pushing heavy things, but other than that, I felt pretty terrific.  I only had 2 sentinal nodes taken out from each side, so I didn't have any problems with mobilities with my arms.  I've been using my 3 pound dumb bells each day to exercise it to make/keep them stronger post surgery, and now they are completely strong and feeling dandy fine! 4 weeks later is when they started to expand my brests with saline solution injections - and that is when the real discomfort started for me!  Surgery seemed like a breeze compared to my ongoing breast reconstruction at the moment - LOL. Having traveled extensively and frequently all my life, I can tell you that Germany is not a country where I would be afraid to travel to.  They are efficient, high tech, good medical facilities with easy access (and they speak English for the most part!). If you were traveling to remote countries or third world, I would advise against it (been there, done that, and it was a scary experience to be in one of their clinics when I came down with something after drinking their water... yikes).    Good luck.
Posts.Title: How did you feel 4 weeks post bilat mastectomy? libby sbmolee
